perturbation.original_text:
4.2 LIMITATION OF WARRANTY AND LIABILITY. LICENSOR DOES NOT MAKE WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, WHETHER
EXPRESS, IMPLIED, RELATED TO OR ARISING OUT OF THE LICENSED MARK OR THIS AGREEMENT.
4.2.1 LICENSOR SPECIFICALLY DISCLAIMS ANY IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS FOR A
PARTICULAR PURPOSE, NON-INFRINGEMENT AND TITLE, AND ALL OTHER WARRANTIES THAT MAY OTHERWISE ARISE FROM
COURSE OF DEALING, USAGE OF TRADE OR CUSTOM.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.2 LIMITATION OF WARRANTY AND LIABILITY. LICENSOR DOES NOT MAKE WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, WHETHER
EXPRESS, IMPLIED, RELATED TO OR ARISING OUT OF THE LICENSED MARK OR THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the disclaimer of implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose, the contract appears to offer these warranties by default. However, since California law presumes these warranties in certain transactions, their omission creates ambiguity and potential liability for the licensor while simultaneously potentially misleading the licensee regarding their rights. This creates a legal risk.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Commercial Code §§ 2314, 2315, which imply warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose unless conspicuously disclaimed.

perturbation.original_text:
4.10 Governing Law and Jurisdiction. The provisions of this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws
of the State of California (excluding any conflict of law rule or principle that would refer to the laws of another jurisdiction). Each Party hereto
irrevocably submits to the jurisdiction of the state and federal courts located in California, in any action or proceeding arising out of or relating to
this Agreement, and each Party hereby irrevocably agrees that all claims in respect of any such action or proceeding must be brought and/or
defended in any such court; provided, however, that matters which are under the exclusive jurisdiction of the federal courts shall be brought in the
Federal District Court for the Central District of California. Each Party hereto consents to service of process by any means authorized by the
applicable law of the forum in any action brought under or arising out of this Agreement, and each Party irrevocably waives, to the fullest extent
each may effectively do so, the defense of an inconvenient forum to the maintenance of such action or proceeding in any such court.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.10 Governing Law and Jurisdiction. The provisions of this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws
of the State of California (excluding any conflict of law rule or principle that would refer to the laws of another jurisdiction). Each Party hereto
irrevocably submits to the jurisdiction of the state and federal courts located in California, in any action or proceeding arising out of or relating to
this Agreement, and each Party hereby irrevocably agrees that all claims in respect of any such action or proceeding must be brought and/or
defended in any such court.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the clause 'provided, however, that matters which are under the exclusive jurisdiction of the federal courts shall be brought in the Federal District Court for the Central District of California' and the clause stating, 'Each Party hereto consents to service of process by any means authorized by the applicable law of the forum in any action brought under or arising out of this Agreement, and each Party irrevocably waives, to the fullest extent each may effectively do so, the defense of an inconvenient forum to the maintenance of such action or proceeding in any such court.' The contract now incorrectly implies that all matters, even those under exclusive federal jurisdiction, can be handled in California state courts. Furthermore, removing the 'service of process' and 'inconvenient forum' waivers creates ambiguity on procedural compliance, potentially leading to jurisdictional challenges.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 28 U.S. Code § 1331 (Federal Question Jurisdiction) and California Code of Civil Procedure regarding service of process and forum non conveniens.

perturbation.original_text:
4.11 Attorney's Fees. In the event any suit or other legal proceeding is brought for the enforcement of any of the provisions of this
Agreement, the Parties hereto agree that the prevailing party shall be entitled to recover from the other party upon final judgment on the merits
reasonable attorneys' fees (and sales taxes thereon, if any), including attorneys' fees for any appeal, and costs incurred in bringing such suit or
proceeding.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.11 Attorney's Fees. In the event any suit or other legal proceeding is brought for the enforcement of any of the provisions of this
Agreement, the Parties hereto agree that the prevailing party *may* be entitled to recover from the other party upon final judgment on the merits reasonable attorneys' fees.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying 'shall be entitled to recover' to 'may be entitled to recover' introduces ambiguity and weakens the prevailing party's right to attorney's fees. While California law generally allows for contractual attorney's fees provisions (Cal. Civ. Code § 1717), making the award discretionary contradicts the original intent and could be interpreted as an unenforceable provision, especially if it unduly favors one party. Omitting the part of sales taxes for attorneys fees and costs is another legal contradiction as well.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code § 1717 (reciprocity of attorney's fees provisions) and general principles of contract interpretation favoring clear and unambiguous language.
